results.headline: Walking With Solitude, and Her Baggage
results.summary_short: “Wild” stars Reese Witherspoon as a woman who takes on an arduous solo trek along the Pacific Crest Trail.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild

results.headline: Where the Biggest Enemy Is Tedium
results.summary_short: The Israeli comedy “Zero Motivation” looks at the monotony of life for two young female soldiers assigned to a remote desert outpost.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Motivation

results.headline: Raising a Defiant Hand Against the Fist of the Law
results.summary_short: In “Ungli,” four young professionals — led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda — set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ungli

results.headline: Go Read a Book, Kid. It Couldn’t Hurt You.
results.summary_short: “The Babadook,” the Australian director Jennifer Kent’s debut feature, is a horror movie full of interlocking ambiguities.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Babadook

results.headline: When Fractions of a Second Can Change Whole Lives
results.summary_short: The documentary “Touch the Wall” follows two world-class swimmers, Kara Lynn Joyce and Missy Franklin.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Touch the Wall

results.headline: From Here (or There) to Eternity
results.summary_short: “The Immortalists,” a documentary directed by David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg, looks at two scientists racing against time and its inevitable consequences.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Immortalists

results.headline: Broken Codes, Both Strategic and Social
results.summary_short: In “The Imitation Game” Benedict Cumberbatch plays Alan Turing, whose code-breaking work helped win World War II yet whose homosexuality led him to face indecency charges in Britain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Imitation Game

results.headline: Who Knew the Classics Could Be So Combative?
results.summary_short: “The Historian” centers on a divorced professor who clashes with a superior and walks an ethical tightrope.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Historian

results.headline: A Doctor Will See You Now
results.summary_short: “Remote Area Medical” chronicles a nonprofit group that stages free clinics in areas that lack access to basic health care.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Remote Area Medical

results.headline: Slashing His Wrists When the Phone Rings
results.summary_short: “Before I Disappear” is Shawn Christensen’s feature-length expansion of his Oscar-winning short, “Curfew.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Disappear

results.headline: Home Sweet Home on the Isolated Ice
results.summary_short: The documentary “Antarctica” reveals the community spirit among residents of the southernmost continent.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antarctica: A Year On Ice

results.headline: A Task Force in Black Tuxedos
results.summary_short: In the animated “Penguins of Madagascar,” the title animals will lose their cuteness if an octopus named Dave (voiced by John Malkovich) has his way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penguins of Madagascar

results.headline: Underlings Again Seek the Upper Hand
results.summary_short: An invention is part of the plot of “Horrible Bosses 2,” a sequel that tries to recapture the zany feel of the original film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Horrible Bosses 2

results.headline: A Secret Falls From the Family Tree, and a Girl’s Identity Branches Out
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Little White Lie,” a girl who grew up viewing herself as Jewish and white gradually begins to realize that her biological father was black.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little White Lie

results.headline: Charles XVI: An Inept Hunter, but You Can Count on Him
results.summary_short: A restored version of the animated “The King and the Mockingbird,” an adaptation of a Hans Christian Andersen story, has a New York run.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Roi et l'oiseau

results.headline: Sifting the Ashes of Bible Belt Church Fires
results.summary_short: Theo Love’s “Little Hope Was Arson” looks at the scars inflicted by 10 church fires over five weeks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Hope Was Arson

results.headline: The Old Country Never Goes Away
results.summary_short: Haitian exiles in New York City are forced to confront the pain of their shared history in “Stones in the Sun.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stones in the Sun

results.headline: A Restless and Turbulent Unconscious
results.summary_short: “The Sleepwalker” is a spare study of two couples that digs into issues about class, domestic abuse, sibling rivalry and mental illness, but refrains from easy answers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sleepwalker

results.headline: Up From Rubble to Lead a Revolution
results.summary_short: The latest installment of the “Hunger Games” films is a vague yet stirring liberation story that echoes real-life struggles against oppression around the world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunger Games: Mockingjay, Part 1

results.headline: A Secret Life in Zurich
results.summary_short: Stefan Haupt’s “The Circle” tells the story of a gay Swiss couple, from their (dramatized) meeting in the 1950s to documentary interviews today.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Der Kreis
